problem: Compute the range of the function $f(x) = \sqrt{x^2}$.
solution: We can see that $f(x) = \sqrt{x^2} = |x|$. (Note that $f(x) \not = x$ since $x$ can be negative.) Because $|x|$ takes on all non-negative values, the range is $\boxed{[0,\infty)}$.
model_solution:
## Step 1: Identify the nature of the function
The function $f(x) = \sqrt{x^2}$ involves the square root of the square of $x$.
## Step 2: Determine the domain of the function
The domain of the function $f(x) = \sqrt{x^2}$ is all real numbers $x$, since the square of any real number is non-negative and the square root of a non-negative number is defined.
## Step 3: Determine the range of the function
The range of the function $f(x) = \sqrt{x^2}$ is all non-negative real numbers, since the square root of any non-negative number is non-negative.

The final answer is: $\boxed{[0,\infty)}$
